One further thing that more than serves to wipe out any
feeling of gratitude among the Japanese towards the
American Army is the suspicion that America is being
driven by strategy to make Japan a base, using her as a
tool for promoting her own military policies in the Far
East. Is not American action in stationing troops in Japan,
in other words, dictated solely by considerations of her
own best interests? This feeling is strengthened by the
fact that when Japan regained her independence the Occupa¬
tion forces stayed on in Japan.
The feelings of various sections of the country and among
various groups: scholars students and intellectuals are not,
however, sufficiently well-defined to be called "anti-
Americanism" being confined, rather, to a sense of insecurity
and helplessness in a.world that contains the atomic and
hydrogen bombs*
And I think these inarticulate feelings might develop into
a strong anti-Americanism, or more likely, a settled frame
of mind permitting a confident approach to relations with
America, The most important problem of the future as far
as Japanese-American relations are concerned is ho?; these
feelings can best be guided into the right channels.
Many thanks, John Ishimoto for exploring the problem one
reads and hears a lot about, but rarely gets to pin down.
And I think, frankly, the concern about "anti-Americanist
is one of the self-conscious nervous tremors of our time*
This is John Lerch in Tokyo bidding you Sayonara until next
week at this time.
